text.text: The Herdergarten wasn’t always a parking lot. It took on many different and very crucial roles throughout the history of Holzkirchen.
Old Holzkirchen from the air (postcard provided by the Musikzug)

Its name (Herder) stems from “shepherd” as the main shepherd kept all of the sheep of this town. He lived in a small shed right at the Herdergarten. At around 1800, this shepherd was not needed anymore due to a communal pasture. Thus, he was let go but given enough money to sustain his further life.

About 40 years later in one of the notorious fires in Holzkirchen, the house burned down but was rebuilt. It hosted a drawing school led by an artistic teacher. However, this institution was removed shortly after to make room for a playground. In 1933, the space even turned into an ice-skating and “Eisstockschießen” (a Bavarian sport similar to curling) ring.
Ice ring in 1933 (from the Holzkirchner Chronicals)
Today, the field has transformed into a parking lot and the building on the side has become a youth center.

But throughout the year, the concrete plane doesn’t always look this empty. The “Musikzug” (a traditionally Bavarian music club and marching band) Holzkirchen organizes a big Bavarian festival every year. It’s called the “Frühlingsfest” (translates to spring festival) and offers traditional music, food, and fun attractions. 10.000 - 15.000 people visit this festival each year.
The Frühlingsfest (photographs provided by the Musikzug)

Mr. Beck (head of the Musikzug) considers this festival to be one of the last truly traditionally Bavarian festivals. He also points out that its existence is necessary for children and teenagers to perform their music. Rather than focusing on the attractions, he thinks learning to play an instrument and having a platform to share this music is important.
Musikzug in action (photographs provided by the Musikzug)

The festival is also a fundamental part of financing the Musikzug which teaches young and old people how to play instruments. This year (2020), the festival had to be cancelled due to the corona pandemic but everyone is hoping for a big comeback next year. And it is unlikely that this local spring festival will ever run out of visitors as it turns a dull parking lot into a traditional and cultural center.

The building in front of you hasn’t always been the town's library, in fact the history this building is very interesting and goes back to when the town was still under the Tegernseer monastery’s control. Back then, which was a couple centuries back, it was used as the “Zehentstadel” where Holzkirchens payments to the monastery were collected. After that in 1827, the building was bought from the monastery to become the new Town Hall. During all this time fires were a common threat in Holzkirchen and eventually the building burned down in 1842. Afterwards it was rebuilt bigger than it had previously had been. Along with Holzkirchens growth, the town hall had to grow as well so in 1896 the boardroom was enlarged. In 1913 a new chandelier was put into the community hall. The picture below shows the marketplace from 1920.

In 1935 the building was the further altered. This process was strongly covered by the press. Sometime later the town hall moved out into a now building directly next to  the old one. Eventually, there was an idea to use it as the town’s library. The plan was set in action and it is still the purpose the building serves today. Nowadays, it doesn't only lend books , but also for example movies, magazines and board games. It is usually open on afternoons during the week.

The farmers' market takes place in front of the city hall in center of Holzkirchen. The marketplace is the heart of this town. Farm owner and market traders from Holzkirchen and surroundings assemble their booths twice a week, on Wednesday and Saturday.

The variety of offerings is huge. There are market stands that sell fruits and vegetables and others that offer cheese, meat and fish. Usually, there are some special stands, too. For example, unique products like wine and bacon from Süd Tirol. The food is ecological, organic and its quality is outstanding.

Many citizens of Holzkirchen enjoy buying their weekly groceries on the farmers' market. Shopping there is not as exhausting as in a supermarket. They do not have to rush, because on the market there is always time for a little chat. Marketeer can also easily answer questions on products. The famers market gives the opportunity to buy high quality local food, which people in Holzkirchen appreciate a lot.

Additionally, there are some special market days which depend on the time of the year. Around Christmas, there is a Christmas market with different booths, for example some with mulled wine and children’s punch. Of course, the marketplace is decorated nicely with fair lights for these occasions. There are also some Bavarian traditional markets like the Johannimarket, Simon-Judi-Market and the Grasmarket.
The famers market plays an important part in Holzkirchen. Not only do you find it twice a week on the marketplace but also in the towns name because Holzkirchen is offically a market community.

The catholic church St Laurentius was built for the first time in the 7th or 8th century in conjunction to the establishment of the monastery Tegernsee. At this time, it was actually a church in the woods, as Holzkirchen was nothing more than a forest and some dirt tracks. Therefore, when a town was founded in the 12th century around the church, it was called Holzkirchen, which literally translates to “wood-church”.
Already on the first coat of arms of Holzkirchen in 1550 St Laurentius was represented and still is in the current one, hence it became one the towns landmarks.
The church is named after the patron Saint Laurentius, a roman deacon and martyr, who died on the 10th of August in 258 AC.

Between 1490 and 1802 the church burnt down seven times, either partially or completely, however she was always time-adapting reconstructed by the cloister. After the monastery was broken up in 1803, Holzkirchen was given to the reigning Elector of Bavaria. Through this new alliance, new laws were administered for example compulsory education.

Today weekday services, Saturday night-Mass and funerals are frequently held in St Laurentius, as well as special events such as annual concerts of local choirs like the “Holzkirchner Liedertafel” and “Cantica Nova”.
To sum it up St Laurentius is as a meeting place for people of any age or religion in Holzkirchen of substantial importance.
The hotel opened for the first time back in 1674. Since then almost everything has changed. When Baltasar Mayr first opened the hotel it was called the Bauernbräu (farmer´s brew).
Hotel 1751

In 1827, under Johann Holfeld, the hotel was renamed from "Bauernbräu" to "Postbräu" and in 1893 a new post office was created at the inner market. As a result of this the „Brauwirt“ became the „Neue Post“ and the „Postbräu“ was renamed to „Alte Post“. In 1982 the whole hotel was renovated. Since 1997 Gabriele Falke and her husband Udo have been taking care of the 43 rooms and the guests from all around the world. Like many other businesses, the hotel has been very much affected by the corona pandemic.

Kultur im Oberbräu is the cultural center of Holzkirchen and combines theater, literature, cabaret, music, concerts, cinema, exhibitions, culinary delights and much more. The FoolsKino, the FoolsTheater, KulturCafe and Kultur im Oberbräu (cinema, theatre, café and ballroom) offer attractions for young and old.

In the 19th century, the building complex was repeatedly (1844, 1875 and 1895, among others) hit by severe fires. Parts of these burnt down predecessor buildings were reused for the new construction. The building in its present form with the exterior dimensions of 60 x 14 meters was erected in 1896 by master builder Karl Stöhr from Munich on behalf of the then owner Hilpoltsteiner. Karl Stöhr became known among other things through the construction of the Deutsches Theater in Munich and a number of hotel buildings and public buildings. In 1997, the market town of Holzkirchen purchased the Oberbräusaal building in order to spare it the fate of demolition, which happened, for example, to the brewhouse of the brewery in the inner courtyard. Extensive renovation and construction measures over many years were necessary to ensure that the ballroom could continue to be used as an event venue.

With more than 230 events in the Festsaal and FoolsTheater as well as over 800 film screenings in the FoolsKino every year, the cultural center of the market town of Holzkirchen has already counted more than 500,000 visitors.

Chapel „Our Dear Ladies“:

Today's cemetery chapel, consisting of a small saddleback roof with ridge turret, was built in 1639 as a so called plague chapel. In 1807 the graveyard of St.Laurentius church was relocated to the chapel and consequently a wall was built around the graveyard and the small chapel.
„Our Dear Lady“ refers to the virgin Mary, mother of God who is very venerated in the Catholic Church. Inside the plague chapel, you can see this small altar:
To get more specific information and some interesting stories, you should listen to the German interview I conducted with Pastor Gottfried Doll.

This is the geographical centre of Holzkirchen: the train station. A brief look at the map shows the train station as the direct centre of this city town. But why has this town evolved so much around the train station?
To answer this question, we have to take a look to the past. 160 years ago the town had absolutely no goods.

The only thing important about the city was the train infrastructure that linked important railway lines of this time. On the one hand the Pachtbahn,brought coal from Miesbach. On the other hand there was the Maximiliansbahn,which was the most important railways line in southern germany, connecting vienna and munich.

The only thing important about the town was the train infrastructure that linked important railway lines of this time: On the one hand, there was the “Pachtbahn” that brought coal from Miesbach and on the other hand there was the “Maximiliansbahn”, which was the most important railway line in southern Germany, connecting the centres of Vienna and Munich. In 1860 the train station became even more important, when the express line Vienna - Paris became a thing. was built. Holzkirchen was the interchange station of that line.

The importance of Holzkirchen began to decline, when the “Haidhauser Bahnhof” in Munich was built in 1871, since then Holzkirchen was not part of any long range lines anymore. But the train station still was relevant for local traffic from the centres of Munich, Rosenheim or Tegernsee.

Another interesting part of this train station is the building because it stands here since circa 100years. Built in 1913, it still stands today. Even though there were a lot of renovations you can still see the similarities between the building in 1913 and today.

This is the station about the “Teufelsgraben” (Devil´s Trench). You will learn some facts and hear two myths about the formation of the Teufelsgraben. If you want to visit this place the parking lot at the federal road with a small gravel path would be a great place to start a trip.

The “Teufelsgraben” begins at lake “Kirchsee” and winds up to the “Mangfalltal” near Grub. Some scientists assume that in the course of the “Würm glacial stage”, the last glacial period in the Alpine foothills, huge glaciers were pushed into the Alpine foothills which made the formation of the Teufelsgraben possible. You can find multiple remains of this time in the Bavarian Alpine foothills. The  “Ammersee”, the “Starnbergersee” and the typical Moraine landscape are such remains raised through bigger glaciers which came from the Alps about 2000 years ago. The water melting from the glaciers created rifts like the “Mühltal” (at Starnberg), the  “Gleißenthal” (south of Munich, from “Deiniger Weiher” to “Deisenhofen”) and our  “Teufelsgraben”.
But in addition to the scientific theories you just heard, there are also some myths about the creation of the Teufelsgraben which you can enjoy now.

The devil once stood near Holzkirchen, leaning on a shovel and pondering what he could do to the people. He looked at the city with fury and hatred because the people of Munich were too Christian for him. Due to their many devotions he could not find a place among them. Then he thought of locking away their water out of revenge and leading the “Isar” to the lake “Chiemsee”. He quickly got to work and started digging at night as if he had got a thousand hands. As he was in full swing, someone appeared. It was the sacristan from “Föching”, who - in order not to oversleep the ringing of prayer - had already gotten up at midnight. When he heard the noise and saw all the beating and shoveling, digging and throwing, and how the earth flew off to the right and left, he asked: "What are you doing?" - The devil growled: "If I want to divert the Isar here, what does that concern you?" - "One might think so," replied the sacristan, "Do you want to get it done by today? It will take you quite a few years!" - "How about a bet for your soul?", replied the devil, "Before the morning bell rings, I'm done digging." - "I'm in" replied the church attendant, "even if I can't win anything". But soon he was horrified by the eerie unknown, set the church clock two hours ahead and rang the prayer bell at 3 o'clock. All the cocks immediately came alive and broke the magic of the night with their crows. But the devil, angry that he had miscalculated his actions, threw away the pimple and shovel, gave up his work and went to hell.“
Did you already enjoy this first story? The next short story will tell you how the devil lost a bet against a poor miller in a very unusual way.

One day, a miller at the Mangfall, who had too little water, made a pact with the devil. The devil had to build a channel from the Isar to his mill for which the miller promised his soul. The next night before the first cockcrow, the devil had to complete the moat and started to work in the darkness with great force. The tremendous pit already reached from “Stumbach” to “Otterfing” and from “Holzkirchen” to “Valley” which fulfilled the miller with great fear and regret. He quickly ran home to the chicken shed and woke up the cock. The cock crowed brightly through the whole neighborhood - and so the miller’s pact with the devil was dissolved.
I hope you liked the short digressions to the historic myths and learned something new about the Holzkirchen region.
Source: Sagen aus dem Isarwinkel, Willibald Schmidt, Bad Tölz, 1936, 1979;
